awd_titl_txt: RUI: D3SC: The Role of Non-Motif Selectivity Determinants in Peptide-Binding Domain Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells receive and respond to local signals to communicate with their environment, and errors in these cell signaling pathways can lead to a number of different human diseases. A significant challenge in describing this and other cellular pathways is that many interactions among signaling proteins rely on just a small number of contacts between their amino acid building blocks, leading to promiscuity and overlap in binding partners.  With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Jeanine Amacher from Western Washington University to investigate how cell signaling proteins can specifically recognize one another with the number of contacts limited to 10 or less amino acids between them. This project characterizes every interacting amino acid involved in protein recognition for one set of proteins along the cell signaling pathway and elucidates how these interactions evolved. In addition, the project provides undergraduate and masters level graduate students with firsthand experience in structural biology and protein biochemistry to prepare them for STEM-related careers. 
 
An important class of protein-protein interactions in the cell involve recognition of short linear motifs (SLiMs) or peptides. These interactions are critical in signaling and trafficking components in the cell, but are often relatively weak in affinity and transient. Examples include kinase, phosphatase, SH2, and PDZ domain-mediated interactions. However, the recognition of only a couple of amino acid positions by SLiM-binding domains results in interaction networks that greatly overlap, rendering the dissection biologically-important interactions nearly impossible based on the analysis of motifs alone. In this project, the PDZ domain is used as a model system to define the role of non-motif selectivity determinants in SLiM- or peptide mediated interactions. PDZ domains recognize the extreme C-terminus of target proteins through binding motifs that are based on only two residues. Likewise, two sequences can bind dramatically different numbers of PDZ domains. For example, the C-terminal sequence of the human papillomavirus E6 oncoprotein (HPV16 E6) interacts with over a dozen PDZ domain containing proteins, while the C terminal sequence of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) interacts with less than five. Both HPV16 E6 and CFTR contain identical motif residues. The overall objectives in this project are to (i) dissect the promiscuity of these two target sequences at non-motif, or modulator, residues and (ii) define the role of modulator residues throughout evolution. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that modulator preferences dictate cellular interaction networks. The principles emerging from this project are applicable to other SLiM-binding domain families.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PI Jeanine Amacher has completed research for NSF award CHE-1904711. This work was primarily conducted at Western Washington University (Bellingham, WA), with collaborations at Western Washington University (WWU), the Institute for Protein Innovation, and the Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth. The award period included training of approximately 20 undergraduate and 4 Master’s students at WWU, several of whom are now in PhD programs or graduate professional schools, or working in the biotechnology industry.

 

The major goals of this award were to investigate non-motif specificity determinants in peptide-binding domain interactions, using the PDZ domain as a model system. PDZ domains are important signaling and trafficking domains in the cell, which are conserved throughout evolution. The binding motifs for PDZ domain interactions historically contain only 2 residue positions, and are thus insufficient to describe the overlapping yet distinct interactomes of PDZ domains or their target sequences. Here, PI Amacher and colleagues used protein biochemistry, computational biology, and structural biology to better understand the critical contributions of non-motif peptide positions to these important protein-protein interactions.

 

PI Amacher and colleagues developed two computational programs to predict PDZ domain targets in any organization with a publicly available proteome. Here, they used choanoflagellates, our closest non-metazoan ancestor, as a model. In one of the programs, potential choanoflagellate PDZ targets were predicted and biochemically tested for PDZ domains that have homologs in the human proteome; therefore, are well conserved in evolution. They confirmed previous studies suggesting that PDZ protein specificity likely arose in each PDZ domain as it first appeared, and complex signaling and trafficking pathways evolved around these established binding preferences. In another program, PI Amacher and colleagues identified conserved amino acid positions in the PDZ peptide-binding cleft that interact directly with target residues, and used these to predict potential PDZ target sequences in proteins without homologs in the human proteome. Again, predictions were verified using protein biochemistry and structural biology/modeling. Through this work, PI Amacher and colleagues crystallized and solved the structures of 4 PDZ domains from choanoflagellates, the first experimentally-determined and available structures of choanoflagellate PDZ domains.

 

In developing a better understanding of the role that non-motif residues play in PDZ specificity, PI Amacher and colleagues also wanted to investigate why certain PDZ-binding sequences, e.g., the C-terminus of the human papillomavirus (HPV)16 E6 oncoprotein, target many PDZ domains whereas others, e.g., the C-terminus of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), bind relatively few. These differences exist despite these two sequences sharing identical motif position amino acids. To study this, they determined binding affinities for 9 PDZ domains known to bind HPV16 E6 and/or CFTR sequences with 8 peptides that included either the wild-type or position-substituted target sequences, as well as used structural alignment with energy minimizations to model PDZ-peptide binding. The results suggested that while single substitutions had relatively small effects on overall binding, the energetic contributions from all non-motif positions successfully determined relative promiscuity. These results have important implications in thinking about other viruses, e.g., influenza, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), rabies, and SARS-CoV-2, that target PDZ protein networks.

 

Although PDZ domains were used as the primary model system in this award period, this award also enabled preliminary studies investigating specificity determinants in bacterial sortase enzymes. These proteins are an important protein engineering tool utilized in sortase-mediated ligation experiments, and experiments revealed that sortase enzymes also recognize their peptide substrates in a position-specific manner. All work described in this Project Outcomes Report is published in peer-reviewed journals, and was the basis of presentations by PI Amacher and students at institutional, regional, and national conferences. Taken together, these studies have significance for elucidating a better understanding of peptide-binding in many domains that bind short protein sequences in biological systems.
